video.title: Python Project - Ameritrade API Stock Screener
video.description:
This course is meant for educational purposes only. The information presented in this video is not investment advice.

Learn how to use the Ameritrade API and program a stock screener with Pandas and Python.

✏️ Course developed by Sam Focht from Python Basics. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCHeNxWGbq_0v2lNCgWplNGQ

Register for the TD Ameritrade API here: https://developer.tdameritrade.com/

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: genmen
topLevelComment.text:
just an alternative to start/end loop:

x = 5456
step = 500
for counter in range(0, x, step):
      print(counter, min(x, counter+step))

replies.author: Kurt Heise
replies.text: In the video he creates a file next to the main one called keys.py with a variable called ameritrade = the api key they give you.  Then in the main file he codes from keys import ameritrade. Idk where the file list for all the companies is in csv form but you can pull that off of thinkorswim if you have it. I just created a short 10 ticket list on excel just to trial run and it worked good.

topLevelComment.author: Good Luck
topLevelComment.text:
@7:40
 "There is a limitation.....to our queries...it is a max...500 works...600 fails...it's somewhere between 500 and 600..."..

A MAX WHAT? 
He then goes into doing this loop to count up to 5456.......Why is he doing this? ......

replies.author: Quah Ming Jun
replies.text: @Rogue Hunter Actually 500 requests isn't to a specific timeframe but rather, 500 ticker requests in one call (batch requests). The rate limit for TD Ameritrade is 120 calls per min.

replies.author: Good Luck
replies.text: @Rogue Hunter yeah i figured that out 10 minutes later once he finished his sentence

replies.author: Rogue Hunter
replies.text: There is normally a limit on API requests, and he is saying he was hitting a limit at around 500 requests in his script. So he was breaking up his requests into chunks of 500 to stay under the API limit. There is no timeframe here so it could be 500 requests per second or 500 requests per millisecond, he never tests for it, but he adds a 1 second delay for a different reason (naming his pickle files) and it works. I don't see a limit mentioned in the API docs, maybe it was a fluke.
